head.title: Jessica's Foot Appears Safe From Amputation

hedline.hl1: Jessica's Foot Appears Safe From Amputation

block.p: LEAD: Jessica McClure's injured right foot apparently will not have to be amputated, but the toddler may lose two toes as a result of her two and a half days trapped in a dry well, a hospital spokeswoman said today.

LEAD: Jessica McClure's injured right foot apparently will not have to be amputated, but the toddler may lose two toes as a result of her two and a half days trapped in a dry well, a hospital spokeswoman said today.

Jessica McClure's injured right foot apparently will not have to be amputated, but the toddler may lose two toes as a result of her two and a half days trapped in a dry well, a hospital spokeswoman said today.

''I think if anything, it would just be those two toes,'' said Stellyce Allen, a spokeswoman for Midland Memorial Hospital where the 18-month-old girl has been cared for since her rescue a week ago from the narrow shaft.

Jessica slid into the 8-inch dry well last week and her foot was jammed at an awkward angle for 58 1/2 hours, cutting off circulation and threatening it with gangrene that doctors had warned could have required amputation of the foot.
But today, as surgeons operated to remove dead skin for the third time, they said the main concern was over two toes, according to Ms. Allen.
Asked if amputation was still a possibility, she said, ''But it will not be for the entire foot.''
Jessica's dramatic rescue last Friday was televised nationally, and she has received thousands of cards and gifts from well-wishers.
The toddler's mood has been improving daily as she continues a diet of solid food, hospital officials said.
